content.description: Start with your left hand in a small undercling and your right hand on a tiny crimp. The left foot is good, but pulling on requires tension. A sidepull and a sloper lead to a good hold. Paste your feet, stand up make an easy topout.
content.location:
This is located on the north face of the Whale Boulder which is right off the trail as you come up to the main Quarry area. If you are looking at

Finger Wrecker

, it's directly behind you.

content.description: Sit start on the obvious jug.  Pull up into an undercling.  The crux is over when you are standing on the start hold, but the top out is still a little tricky.  I guess that's where the problem gets its name....
content.protection: Perfect flat landing with one pad....
content.location:
When the approach trail enters the right side of the quarry, this is on the boulder on the left.  The Problem "

Something to Do

" is facing you, this problem is on the opposite, south-facing,  side of the boulder.

content.description:
This is the second from the right most route in the main Quarry Wall area.  It ascends a slightly awkward hands-to-fist size cracks where your elbows or shoulders seem to get in the way.  Some may feel the rating a bit stiff, but apparently some solo the route (not me).

If you set up an anchor up and left, you can TR the challenging Offwidth Bulge to the left.
content.protection:
Cams #0.75 to #3.5 (old size) Camalots work. A belay is a bit challenging to find. You can belay above the

Offwidth Bulge

with #0.5, 0.75, 1, 4 (old size) Camalots.

Per

Matt Harahush

: there are now a pair of bolts to the right of the top that can be used for a TR.
content.location:
This is the 2nd climb from the right. It goes up to the left side to the thin block above.  It is just left of

The Mummy

.

content.description: This is the old Hank Caylor project as noted in the Fixed Pin guidebook.  Start with a few finger locks and a crimp out left and gain some insecure jamming or double gaston action on decent feet.  Plug a piece and execute the difficulty crux to a jug, then move up on decent holds and place a creative piece or two and embark on the second crux to the tufa-esque feature and the jug on top.  Short but very sweet!
content.protection: If you're launching up this thing, then you can probably figure your own gear, but here's what I used...1 #0.4 Camalot, 1 #0.75 Camalot, 1 #0.5 Camalot, 1 #2 Camalot, and a #4 brass RP.  There is more room for gear if you are creative.
content.location:
This route is up to the left of

Marry Me, Becky

.  It is the obvious seam to the two bolt anchor 40 feet up.

climbs.name: Stimulus
climbs.fa: Jimmy Menendez, Mark Rolofson, and Kaelen Williams, Feb. 6, 2009

content.description: Very bouldery route.  First crux can be done either in the crack (Jimmy and Mark's beta) or on the arete (my preferred way).  After this is a couple bolts of 5.10-ish climbing to a stance, then the second crux, pulling through the bulge to a gaston.  This is more powerful than the first crux but felt easier.
content.location: On the right side between two crack routes (the right one is bolted on the upper half).  Goes through the obvious bulge.

content.description: Start with your left hand on a blocky hold and your right on an okay edge, both around shoulder height. A cool pebble works for a foot. Make a long move to a good hold and a slopey dish to stand up over the bulge. Finish an easier topout. This is nothing special but good for a circuit. Let's face it, you are bouldering at The Quarry because you don't have time to go somewhere good.
content.location:
This is on the left side of the south face of the Whale Boulder. It is 5 feet left of

South Arête

but uses all independent holds.

content.description: Start matched on a good edge at head height and go up. There is some crappy looking rock on this one, but I didn't pull anything down. This is nothing special but good for a circuit. Let's face it, you are bouldering at The Quarry because you don't have time to go somewhere good.
content.location:
It is on the Whale Boulder, around the left from

Something To Do

. The starting hold is on the left of the blunt arête. This can be climbed on independent holds from

Something to Do

and

Southwest Face

.

content.description: The problem climbs the east face of the boulder starting on the right by a hand crack.  Move up to the left on good edges to the top out.  Some of the edges look a little fragile so beware.
content.location: Somthing to Do is located on the East Side of the Whale Boulder.  This is the first boulder encountered when entering the quarry on the approach trail. It is left of the trail when approaching.  You can downclimb from the northwest corner of the boulder.

content.description:
Silver Bullet is the 1st route left of the most obvious line (

Bone Crusher

) on the buttress.  It climbs a finger crack in a left-facing dihedral through a crux bulge and out a final roof to a double bolt anchor.

Start with a tricky boulder problem through flaky rock to a hand slot and the first gear. A good spot is recommended.  Then fingers for ~50, through a crux bulge and a final stance before the last 25 of climbing through a fun roof.
content.protection: Doubles or triples in finger sized cams and a couple hand-sized pieces.  All three of the routes on the main buttress can be toproped, unfortunately its tricky to get over the edge to the anchors.   Up top you will find a crack and a bolt, rappel from here over the lip (careful loose rock!) to the anchors on any of the routes.

content.description:
This is the "perfect" hand crack, 4th route from the right in the Quarry area.  Throw in a #0.75 from the ground.  Start up on the left, left hand cross over jam, get your feet into the crack, jam slippery flared hands.  Mid-crack is probably the crux with a long reach to a mediocre jam.  Cruise to the Fixe rap bolts.

Others have also commented that this route feels stiff for a 9 (given in the guidebook). Apparently some solo the route (not me).  Personally, I thought it was hard for 5.9.
content.protection: Set of cams to a #2 Camalot with some extras in the fat fingers to hands sizes.
content.location: This is the 5th route from the right.

content.description: The crux is getting to the ledge. It has good fingers. There is sketchy rock to get to the anchor. Use a directional cam after the lower section to keep the rope out of the crack.
content.location: This is left of Frankies stuff.

content.description:
This starts on the same flat jug as

The Whale

but goes left to crimpy sid pulls. Flip the right hand, bump the left up, and toe scum the right foot to keep balanced. Cross your right hand to a slopey, crimpy, semi-gaston. Reach the left high to a tiny crimp, step up, reach the right to a horrible pinch, and see if your tendons hold out long enough to get you to the jug.
content.protection: A single pad is sufficient. Watch out for the boulder to climbers left. It's sharp and directly in the fall line.

content.description: This route has the look of a moderate, but further investigation, reveals a powerful and thin crux.
content.location: Climb the nice arete in the center of Quarry Wall.

content.description: Get off the ground and you're in the clear. The highlight is the low angle, lightning bolt crack up high. It is spooky and loose. Just don't pull outward.
content.location:
This is just left of

Sharkcicle

.

climbs.name: Recession 2016
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson & Bobbi Bensman on January 21, 2016

content.description:
This is a 2 bolt direct start to "

Recession Arete

", joining the route at the 2nd bolt. Stick clip the 1st bolt. Vertical face & rounded arete moves lead up the prow with the crux at the 2nd bolt. Reach good holds, & make 3rd clip (2nd bolt on

Recession Arete

). Continue up "

Recession Arete

. The second crux of the climb is the crux of "

Recession Arete

", which is technical & slippery slab climbing.

This direct start was bolted on January 2, 2016, prior to the start of new JCOS bolting regulations. Thanks to Kirk Miller & Troy Tablock for their help.
content.location:
Start just right of "

Depression

" on flat, grassy ground. The start to "

Recession Arete

" is uphill right 12-15 feet off a block.

content.description: Lowball! Start in mono for the right hand and on a crimp around left. An obvious low, crumbling slab of rocks down to the left is off. Work your way up both aretes, and establish yourself on the top rail. Traverse right until you can top out. Possibly this could be topped out directly, but I couldn't on this day; that would make it much harder.
content.location:
It is on a small boulder about eight feet tall just south of the Cave Boulder (with '

Alto

' on it). Find it north and slightly uphill from the Culo Boulder.

climbs.name: One Night
climbs.fa: equipped: Taylor Roy and Justen Sjong 1/12, FA: Taylor Roy

content.description:
One Night is a very unique route that requires a diverse set of skills and the ability to relax and recover at awkward rest stances.

Undulating between less than vertical and slightly overhanging, the route basically breaks down to 5.11a crack climbing, to back-to-back V6, V7, V6 boulder problems, and then some 5.10 to a V5 dihedral.  The beginning will test your crack skills and faith in trad gear.  The first crux is all about slopers and body power.  The second crux involves small edges and horrible smears.  The final crux will test your body position and faith in friction.

Climb the first 25 feet of

Frank's Wild Years

, and traverse right around an arete using a nice hand rail.  After clipping the first bolt, compress your way up the steep face using an undercling feature and a slopey arete until you can stand on the hand rail.  Once you have recovered, crimp some small edges, paste your feet on nothing, do a hard move to a right hand gaston, and move right until you can stand on a set of small edges.  With the end of the difficulties just feet away, get set up on a left-facing feature, stand up on two buttery ripples and make a committing move to the "campus rung", then work your feet up and toss for a huge jug.  Mantle onto the shelf of

Frank's Wild Years

, climb up the easy crack, and finish on the difficult corner of

Banquet

.

This is such a finicky, yet brilliant route.  It gets only three stars, because the rock quality leaves a bit to be desired.
content.protection:
Frank's Wild Years

requires gear from a blue TCU to a yellow Camalot.  Bring a runner for the piece that protects the traverse around the arete.

The rest of the route is protected with bolts and a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is on the left end of the Quarry Wall.  Locate

Frank's Wild Years

, then find the bolts that start about 25 feet up and to the right.

content.description: Start laying down on a good left hand rail and right hand crimp. Find an obvious right foot, and do whatever works with your left. Pull up the face and arete of the boulder until you hit a swell pocket and, ultimately, the very good summit of this fine climb. Top out awkwardly.
content.protection: A pad or two. There is tailbone explosion potential.
content.location: This is on the small boulder just south of the Pocket Rocket Boulder. It is easily spotted if you are looking towards the Quarry Wall.

content.description: This wide crack bulges out just at the point where you cannot chimney inside it anymore.  A few true offwidth moves will be needed to round the steep part and get back into the slot above.  Short but fully valid.
content.location: This is on the right side of the quarry, it is the 3rd crack from the right.

climbs.name: The Mummy
climbs.fa: Josh Gross, Dan Levison, Madoline Gross

content.description: I am sure this has been soloed before, but this neat feature provides a nice moderate route up its southern arete.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the "Quarry Wall".

content.description:
AKA The Whale Direct. From the starting jug on

The Whale

and

Scotland Wales

, take the path of most resistance straight up the face. Use a slopey crimp for the right hand and a slopey sidepull for the left, and gun for the flat top. There are lots of options for feet to keep both the giants and the midgets happy.

It is too short to earn many stars, but it has solid rock and nice powerful moves. This is worthwhile if you lugged a pad up the hill.
content.protection: Flat landing on a shorty... one pad is plenty.
content.location: On the whale boulder between The Whale and Scotland Wales.

content.description:
This route starts with some fingers and hands then fists at the top.  The crux, especially if you are short or have small hands, is getting yourself into the top section.  It's wide and flaring for a move or two, then there's great fist jams and face/arete features.

If I have the wrong name with this route, let me know and I'll change it.
content.protection: Standard rack.  There are two bolts at the top with quick links.  There are also two more bolts with chains at the very top, set back 3 or 4 feet.  With a two 4 foot runners you can set up an easy top rope.  There is a fixed #0 TCU about 1/3 height.
content.location: This route is located to the east of the main area.  If you walk along the base to the east and look up, this will be the first set of anchors that you come to.

content.description:
This is a line that is probably ~100m west / left of the left end of The Quarry Wall routes.  There are a few lines over here, but mostly the routes peter out after 35-45 feet.  This one sort of catches your eye as you walk under it going to The Quarry Wall or to the East Quarry.  It may be easier for a smaller climber with smaller hands.

Start below a dihedral with a crack.  The crack seems to be tight hands to off fingers and a bit tight for the toes.  After about 35 feet, the climbing eases dramatically in difficulty, but you must go another 40 feet to top out.

Walkoff ~ 60m to the left with a short downclimb at the end.  It is a bit loose, so take your time.

Oh yeah, if this is your line, let me know, and I'll correct the info.
content.protection: Wireds, a #9 hex, cams to a #3 Camalot.  The anchor was a #3 Camalot and a medium wired.
content.location: This is to the left of The Quarry Wall's left end by maybe 100m.

content.description: Stick clip first bolt, this is a very unique route, it has a cool arete section leads to jugs through a bulge followed by a thin move to reach upper roof. Next comes an Inspector Gadget crux (long move), finish this one off with a tweaky move to the anchor. Mark Rolofson's years of route development shine through this masterpiece.
content.location:
Kleptocracy is located right of "

Bone Crusher

".

content.description:
This is the climb that starts in the crack just to the left of

The Short Tour

that leads to a steep slab protected by a few bolts. The crux is high and well-protected; however, the crack down low is rather insecure, and the gear I found was pretty iffy. I chose to give this an R rating due to the insecure moves in the crack over questionable gear. The crack is probably 11-ish.
content.protection: If you're jumping on this, you can probably figure out pro. Small cams to #2 Camalot and medium stoppers should do it.

content.description:
This was named after the album by the amazing and legendary Tom Waits....

The leftmost of the three main lines, Frank's Wild Years climbs a crack just left of the prow to a pumpy rising hand traverse.  This leads to a cramped rest in the corner, and then the crux -- a few campus moves on jugs.  There is an unclippable fixed wire here that is designed to keep the rope out of the crack -- please do not remove it.  Above this a no hands rest preceeds a final awkward lieback up slightly lower quality rock to a bolted anchor.
content.protection: Double set of cams, wires, and a very small cam (blue Alien was almost too big) protects the crux well.

climbs.name: Frank's Tame Years
climbs.fa: Joseph Crotty and Mike Cichon, Winter, 2008

content.description:
This has mostly good hands and a move or two of .10a where it pinches down.  Join

Frank's Wild Years

where it cuts right (i.e., .11a/b).
content.protection: SR with a few extra hand-sized pieces.
content.location:
Start 30' left of

Frank's Wild Years

. Climb the 5.10 hand crack in the right-facing corner, and join

Frank's Wild Years

.

content.description: Finger Wrecker climbs a finger crack on the south side of the boulder.  The crack is sharp and painful, but the locks are great.  It can be made harder with a sit start but either way, it is only a few moves to the top out.
content.location: This is on a rectangular block that is about 8' high.  It is about 10' north of the Whale Boulder and is directly to the south of the Crill-Mendez route.  You can get down easily to the left of the crack.

content.description: Start off with a small boulder problem to a rest then the fun beginnings with a bear hugging section and the true crux. Just when you think it's over, there is a slab crux followed by moderate climbing to the anchor.
content.location:
This is just right of "

Kleptocracy

".

content.description: This has a funky start, it is best to stick clip first bolt. Thuggy stemming leads to a slab crux, followed by a neat arete section and thin move to the anchor.
content.location: This is the East-facing wall on pillar in the center of the Quarry Wall.

content.description:
This was originally climbed to reach the ledge above the "

Recession Arete

", crack worming leads to a face move to the anchor.
content.location:
This is left of "

Recession Arete

" and shares the anchor with it.

content.description: Climb the handcrack for about 30 feet until it trends left and gets a little broken. At this point, step right onto the arete and climb straight up to a handcrack through a bulge. Follow this and face climb to the top. Belay from gear at the top. Scramble down and east to descend.
content.location: About 50 meters west of the quarry is another little amphitheater. Look for a nice handcrack below the highest chunk of rock.

content.description: Stand start on the lieback rail. Find a small foot out right, ascend the seam, and find the jugs up high. Pull over the rounded top.
content.location: This is on the east side of the Culo Boulder. If you look west from The Whale Boulder, it's the obvious big rock with the arch overhang.

content.description:
This is the supposedly easiest crack system in this area as of late 2008.  Find this loose, wide, double crack system in a slot.  The rock is quite loose and flaky, shedding pounds of rock even well after its first ascent.  Squirm into the fissure, stand on loose footholds, thrutch, arm bar, switch directions, and get established about 10 feet up.  Silt can and will cover that left jug inside.  Find easier climbing until you get to ~30 feet up.  Here, there are some decidely loose and threatening blocks lightly embedded in the shifting silt.  If wise, move left to finish as for the 9 route (

The Short Tour

) to the left up to a pair of Fixe rap bolts.

Note, getting to the anchors from above for a TR involves a belayed scramble down loose terrain.

Some may feel the rating a bit stiff (given in the guidebook), but apparently some solo the route (not me).

Addendum: the rating I listed comes from the guidebook.  I would up the rating.
content.protection: Cams up to a couple of old style #5 Camalot size or the largest Big Dudes are handy.
content.location: Find this as the 4th crack system from the right in this Quarry area.

content.description:
Bone Crusher (sometimes referred to as Bone Collector) is the line to do on the wall.  It is the rightmost of the three climbs at the main wall (the one visible from the road) and offers continuously high quality, difficult climbing.

Begin in a slightly loose, difficult to protect slot and work up to good gear and a rest on a ledge out right.  From here some interesting moves lead up to another rest at a jug, and then the business begins:  Climb up to a small wedged flake below the steep, bulging wall above, and then jam and/or layback your way up the powerful splitter fingercrack to a stance in a slot.  A few more strenuous moves lead to a bolted anchor.

Good training for your free solo of

Moonlight Buttress

.
content.protection: It is possible to place a #1 Camalot at the very beginning and very end of the route, but both placements are optional.  All the rest of the gear is smaller -- a triple set is nice.  No stoppers or draws needed.

content.description: Start matched on an obvious crimp low on the southeast arete, and work your way directly up and over, staying as true to the arete as possible.
content.location: It is on the southeast arete of the Moby Dick Boulder.

content.description: On the overhang facing south on the Culo Boulder, find the low, left hand crimp and low, right hand sloper on the east side arete. Figure your feet out, and work your way out to the tip. Pull over the top.
content.protection: I'd recommend two or three pads and a spotter. The east side has a nasty ~12 foot fall into talus.
content.location: This ascends the obvious overhang on the Culo Boulder.

content.description:
Climb

Silver Bullet

to a ledge break. Head left on thin tips crack. Then climb left and head up the steep, left-facing corner. It has a boulder problem crux with some trad funk/ movement to finish off the pitch. This makes for a harder finish to "

Silver Bullet

".
content.protection: 3 bolts, 1 or 2 extra tips pieces are nice.

content.description:
I have been playing around on the boulders up at Quarry on breaks between classes, and there seems to be some previously over-looked potential (unless this problem already has an ascent, in which case contact me and I will change the info accordingly).

Start with a left hand on a crimp and right hand pinching the arete. Smear the left foot and heel hook the right around the corner. Pull up to suspicious looking pinches (chipped?) with the right hand and good crimps and edges with the left. Deceivingly steep!

Walk off the back side.
content.protection: Three pads are ideal as the landing is tight and there is a menacing boulder to your back if you fall from up high.
content.location:
This problem is on the west side of a sharp, angling boulder 25' to the west of The Whale Boulder. If you are looking at

The Whale

(V2), it is directly behind you.

content.description: Start in the low underclings with good feet, and move out left to a great crimp. Figure the feet out, and move straight up and over this boulder.
content.location: This is directly north of the Culo Boulder and next to the main Quarry Wall. It forms a cave with the main wall.

content.description: Start sitting on a left hand sloper and a small, right hand crimp. Figure the feet out, and throw out right to the arete, trying not to hit the boulder behind you. Find a bad left hand, set yourself out, and gain the good jug at the top.
content.location: Turn completely around if you're looking at 'Moby Dick' on the Whale Boulder. The slightly overhanging block with a boulder right next to it is what you're looking for.

content.description: Start with your right hand on a sloping arete and your left hand on a crimp. Find thin foot holds, and climb up and across to a jug hold on the arete. From here, find a solid right foot hold in a yellow pocket, and push your left foot to a good incut. Stand, grab the sloper, and top out (don't fall).
content.location:
West of The Whale Boulder sits an egg shaped rock laying towards the north.

Coordinates are: 39°46'16.5"N 105°12'21.5"W.
